question: What is a 'cultivating raiyat' according to the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950?
answer: A 'cultivating raiyat' is a raiyat or an under-raiyat who holds land by cultivating it either by himself or by members of his family or by servants or by bargadars or by or with the aid of hired labourers or with the aid of partners.
law_reference: SECTION 9
context: In this Act, unless there is anything repugnant to the subject or context, (9) 'cultivating raiyat' or 'cultivating under-raiyat' means a raiyat or an under-raiyat, as the case may be, who holds land by cultivating it either by himself or by members of his family or by servants or by bargadars or by or with the aid of hired labourers or with the aid of partners.

question: What does 'derelict tea garden' refer to in the context of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950?
answer: A 'derelict tea garden' refers to a parcel or group of parcels of land held under single management which was held, settled or leased for the purpose of cultivation or manufacture of tea, or which has contained or contains tea bushes, and which has been notified by the Government to be a derelict tea garden and includes all buildings on such land.
law_reference: SECTION 9
context: Provided that in notifying a parcel or parcels of land as a derelict tea garden, the Government may have regard to- (i) whether such land is planted to the extent of less than 15 per cent of its area with tea of which no substantial proportion has been planted in the previous 5 years; and (ii) the opinion of the Tea Board as to whether the area planted with tea more than 7 years previously has produced per acre in the last 3 years less than 25 per cent of the average production per acre of the whole area planted with tea in the Province for that period.

question: What does 'encumbrance' mean in relation to an estate, tenure, holding, tenancy or land under this Act?
answer: Encumbrance means any mortgage, charge, lien, sub-tenancy, easement or other right or interest created by the holder thereof on such estate, tenure, holding, tenancy or land or in limitation of his own interest therein.
law_reference: SECTION 10
context: In this Act, unless there is anything repugnant to the subject or context, (10) 'encumbrance', in relation to any estate, tenure, holding, tenancy or land, means any mortgage, charge, lien, sub-tenancy, easement or other right or interest created by the holder thereof on such estate, tenure, holding, tenancy or land or in limitation of his own interest therein.

question: What is a 'registered' document in the context of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950?
answer: A 'registered' document is one registered under any Act for the time being in force for the registration of documents.
law_reference: SECTION 11
context: In this Act, unless there is anything repugnant to the subject or context, (11) 'registered', in relation to any document, means registered under any Act for the registration of documents.

question: What is a 'proprietor' in the context of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950?
answer: A 'proprietor' means a person owning, whether in trust or for his own benefit, an estate or a part of an estate.
law_reference: SECTION 20
context: In this Act, unless there is anything repugnant to the subject or context, (20) 'proprietor', in relation to a person, means a person owning, whether in trust or for his own benefit, an estate or a part of an estate.

question: What is the right of pre-emption under section 96?
answer: The right of pre-emption under section 96 allows a portion or share of a holding of a raiyat to be sold to a co-sharer tenant in the holding by inheritance or to a person to whom sale can be made under section 90.
law_reference: Section 96
context: The State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950

question: When can an application under sub-section (1) be dismissed?
answer: An application under sub-section (1) shall be dismissed unless the applicant or applicants, at the time of making it, deposit in the Court the amount of the consideration money of the sold holding or portion or share as stated in the notice under section 89 or in the deed of sale, as the case may be, and an amount calculated at the rate of twenty five per centum of the amount referred to in clause (a), and an amount calculated at the rate of eight per centum simple annual interest upon the amount referred to in clause (a) for the period from the date of the execution of the deed of sale to the date of filing of the application for preemption.
law_reference: Section 96
context: The State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950

question: How much compensation is required for the application under section 96?
answer: The amount calculated at the rate of twenty five per centum of the amount referred to in clause (a) for the period from the date of the execution of the deed of sale to the date of filing of the application for preemption.
law_reference: Section 96
context: The State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950

question: Who can apply to the Court for the sale of a portion of a raiyat?
answer: Co-sharer tenants by inheritance or a person to whom sale can be made under section 90.
law_reference: Section 96
context: The State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950

question: When does the Court have the right to apportion the holding or portion?
answer: The Court shall apportion the holding or the portion or share among the applicants or applicants who have joined in the original application under sub-section (6) within such period as it may fix.
law_reference: Section 96
context: The State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950

question: What is the purpose of Section 18 of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950?
answer: Section 18 of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950 mandates that when an order is made under Section 17, the Revenue Officer must record specific details in the record-of-rights. This ensures that the record is comprehensive and accurate as per prescribed guidelines.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part IV, Chapter IV, Section 18

question: Who is responsible for recording the particulars in the record-of-rights under Section 18?
answer: The Revenue Officer is responsible for recording the necessary particulars in the record-of-rights as per the order made under Section 17 of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part IV, Chapter IV, Section 18

question: What happens if the Revenue Officer fails to record the required particulars in the record-of-rights?
answer: While the Act does not specify penalties for non-compliance, the failure to record the required particulars may lead to procedural delays or inaccuracies in land records, which could affect the rights of the landowners or tenants under the Act.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part IV, Chapter IV, Section 18

question: What are the particular details that must be recorded in the record-of-rights under Section 18?
answer: The particular details to be recorded in the record-of-rights under Section 18 are those that may be prescribed by the authorities. These details are typically related to land ownership, tenancy rights, and other relevant information as determined by the law.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part IV, Chapter IV, Section 18

question: What is the significance of Section 18 in the context of land records?
answer: Section 18 ensures that the record-of-rights is prepared or revised in a structured and legally mandated manner, which is crucial for maintaining accurate and reliable land records that reflect the rights of individuals under the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part IV, Chapter IV, Section 18

question: Under what circumstances is Section 18 applicable?
answer: Section 18 is applicable when an order is made under Section 17 of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950. This typically occurs during the preparation or revision of the record-of-rights as part of the land reform process.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part IV, Chapter IV, Section 18

question: What does it mean to 'record particulars' in the record-of-rights?
answer: To 'record particulars' in the record-of-rights means to systematically document specific information related to land ownership, tenancy rights, and other relevant details as required by law, ensuring clarity and legal compliance.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part IV, Chapter IV, Section 18

question: Can the Revenue Officer decide which particulars to record under Section 18?
answer: No. The Revenue Officer must record the particulars as prescribed by the law. The specific details to be recorded are determined by the authorities and are not subject to the officer's discretion.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part IV, Chapter IV, Section 18

question: What is the relationship between Sections 17 and 18 of the Act?
answer: Section 17 authorizes the making of an order for the preparation or revision of the record-of-rights, while Section 18 mandates that the Revenue Officer must record specific details in the record-of-rights as per the order made under Section 17.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part IV, Chapter IV, Section 18

question: What happens if the record-of-rights is not prepared or revised as per Section 18?
answer: Failure to prepare or revise the record-of-rights as per Section 18 may result in incomplete or inaccurate land records, which could lead to legal disputes or challenges regarding property rights under the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part IV, Chapter IV, Section 18

question: What is the meaning of 'cesses' under Section 2 of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950?
answer: Under Section 2(1) of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, 'cesses' include local rates levied under the Assam Local Rates Regulation, 1879. This means that any local rates or taxes collected under that regulation are considered as 'cesses' under this Act.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part I, Chapter I, Section 2

question: What are the examples of 'charitable purpose' under Section 2 of the Act?
answer: Under Section 2(2) of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, 'charitable purpose' includes relief of the poor, education, medical relief, and the advancement of any other object of general public utility. This means that any activity aimed at benefiting the public in these ways qualifies as a charitable purpose.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part I, Chapter I, Section 2

question: Who is considered as a 'Collector' under Section 2 of the Act?
answer: Under Section 2(3) of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, 'Collector' means the Collector of a district and includes a Deputy Commissioner and such other officers as may be appointed by the Government to perform all or any of the functions of a Collector under this Act. This includes various officers who act in the role of the Collector.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part I, Chapter I, Section 2

question: What is the definition of 'complete usufructuary mortgage' under Section 2 of the Act?
answer: Under Section 2(6) of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, 'complete usufructuary mortgage' means a transfer by a tenant of the right of possession in any land for the purpose of securing the payment of money or the return of grain advanced or to be advanced by way of loan. The loan is deemed to be extinguished by the profits arising from the land during the period of the mortgage.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part I, Chapter I, Section 2

question: What is the meaning of 'consolidation' under Section 2 of the Act?
answer: Under Section 2(7) of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, 'consolidation', used with respect to holdings, means the re-distribution of all or any of the areas of land comprised in the holdings for the purpose of rendering separate holdings more compact by reducing the total number of separate plots. This helps in making land management more efficient.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part I, Chapter I, Section 2

question: What is a 'co-operative society' under Section 2 of the Act?
answer: Under Section 2(8) of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, 'co-operative society' means a society registered or deemed to be registered under the Co-operative Societies Act, 1912, or the Bengal Co-operative Societies Act, 1940. This includes societies registered under either of these two Acts.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part I, Chapter I, Section 2

question: Who is considered a 'cultivating raiyat' under Section 2 of the Act?

question: What is a 'derelict tea garden' under Section 2 of the Act?
answer: Under Section 2(9a) of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, a 'derelict tea garden' means any parcel or group of parcels of land held under single management which was held, settled or leased for the purpose of cultivation or manufacture of tea. It also includes all buildings on such land. The Government may notify such land as a derelict tea garden based on certain criteria.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part I, Chapter I, Section 2

question: What is the definition of 'Director of Land Records and Surveys' under Section 2 of the Act?
answer: Under Section 2(9b) of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, 'Director of Land Records and Surveys' includes Additional Director of Land Records and Surveys. This means that the Additional Director is considered part of the definition of the Director.

question: What is the meaning of 'encumbrance' under Section 2 of the Act?

question: What is the definition of 'village' under Section 2 of the Act?
answer: Under Section 2(29) of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, 'village' means the area defined, surveyed and recorded as a district and separate village in any survey made by, or under the authority of, the Government. If no such survey has been made, the Collector may declare an area to constitute a village with the sanction of the Board of Revenue.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part I, Chapter I, Section 2

question: What is the definition of 'year' or 'agricultural year' under Section 2 of the Act?
answer: Under Section 2(30) of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, 'year' or 'agricultural year' means the Bengali year commencing on the first day of Baishakh. This is used to determine the agricultural calendar for the purposes of the Act.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part I, Chapter I, Section 2

question: What is the meaning of 'tenure' under Section 2 of the Act?
answer: Under Section 2(28) of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, 'tenure' means the interest of a tenure-holder or an under-tenure holder. This refers to the legal right or interest a person has in land or property under tenancy.

question: What is the definition of 'tenant' under Section 2 of the Act?
answer: Under Section 2(27) of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, 'tenant' is defined as a person who holds land under a lease or other tenure. This includes both the tenant and the under-tenant.

question: What is the meaning of 'tenure-holder' under Section 2 of the Act?
answer: Under Section 2(28) of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, 'tenure' means the interest of a tenure-holder or an under-tenure holder. A 'tenure-holder' is a person who holds land under a lease or other tenure, and has the right to occupy and use the land.

question: What is the definition of 'under-tenure holder' under Section 2 of the Act?
answer: Under Section 2(28) of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, 'under-tenure holder' is a person who holds land under the tenure of another person. This refers to a tenant who is subject to the rights and obligations of the original tenant.
